title: Will North Korea conduct a nuclear test before 1 January 2017?
preds: Either yesterday's seismic event was a real nuclear test, in which case my prediction today would be discarded, or else the experts would be unable to confirm that it was  a real test.  Yes, there was an earthquake in the right place for a test.  Does North Korea often experience natural earthquakes of this magnitude in that area? A search of USGS archives shows that yesterday's earthquake coincided in three dimensions with a verified test on 2009-05-25 00:54:43 and that those two were only a few miles away from two other verified tests. However -- I notice that there is no source identified for how to resolve this question. While I find it far fetched that a 5.1 earthquake could occur with the same epicenter as a prior confirmed nuclear explosion, it is not impossible. Comparison class: each previous test occurred a few miles from any prior test(s). Yesterday's test was co-located with a previous one. Would it make sense to dig out the same tunnel where a previous test occurred, despite fractured rocks and radioactivity? Alternatively, given that the region is tectonically active, could the prior test have destabilized a dormant fault, leading to North Korea taking advantage of this event by -- gasp -- lying? Not likely, but the experts will be looking for other evidence to confirm that this was a nuclear test, for example https://www.ctbto.org/press-centre/press-releases/2013/ctbto-detects-radioactivity-consistent-with-12-february-announced-north-korean-nuclear-test/
What is the resolution criteria, in terms of doubts about North Koreas claims etc. ?

http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/news/2016/01/03/0200000000AEN20160103000700315.html SEOUL, Jan. 3 (Yonhap) -- North Korea may be preparing to test its thermonuclear weapons capabilities at its Punggye-ri nuclear test site, a South Korean military unit responsible for nuclear defense said Sunday. . . . "We can't discount the possibility that the North's excavation of a new tunnel at its Punggye-ri test site could be designed for thermonuclear weapons tests," said the command, under the direct control of the Defense Ministry. "Considering its research of nuclear technology, its history of underground and projectile tests, and elapsed time since its nuclear development, North Korea has the foundation for thermonuclear weapons."
. . . 
In October, Seoul's National Intelligence Service reported to lawmakers that Pyongyang was preparing for its fourth nuclear test, although a test is not imminent. The CBR Defense Command said should North Korea carry out its fourth nuclear test, it will take a new format. "The North could detonate its boosted fission weapon, but we don't believe it is yet capable of directly testing hydrogen bombs," it added.  In December, North Korean leader Kim Jong-un stated that his country had developed hydrogen bombs, though the claim was met with skepticism by experts.  The CBR Defense Command added the North may also be building a light water reactor to produce tritium. "Technologically advanced nations have tested and developed boosted fission weapons about 10 years after their initial nuclear tests," the command said. "North Korea, 15 years after developing its nuclear capability, may be going ahead with heavy hydrogen production and warhead design. The North, however, doesn't appear to be in the final stages of completing its hydrogen bombs."
~~~~~~~
http://www.ibtimes.com/north-korea-preparing-thermonuclear-weapon-tests-report-2247006 Countries, working to produce nuclear weapons, usually first develop weapons that use nuclear fission to break larger atoms, such as Uranium and Plutonium, into smaller atoms. Thermonuclear weapons or fusion weapons. . .  are more complicated to make. It takes countries many years to independently develop the technology needed to create a fission bomb and then make the subsequent jump to fusion weapons.  However, as part of making fusion weapons, some countries develop “boosted” fission bombs which use a small amount of fusion to boost the fission process, releasing more energy.
. . .

Any perceived threats to its sovereignty or it's right to pursue, test and develop nuclear and missile technology is often met with derision; additionally, perceived threats to what it considers it sovereign territory and borders is often met with more threats (the US and South Korea primarily) and 'tests' (ie., launching of missiles or deterrent technology) to deter it's rivals. Just in case anyone is altering a forecast on the basis of news about Ban Ki Moon's upcoming visit to North Korea – no such thing is on his schedule. News of any sort about North Korea tends to be erroneous and misleading regardless of the news sources. For example, last year many forecasters got weak Brier scores (median 0.305) on the question “Will Kim Jong Un meet a head of state from one of the G7 countries, South Korea, China, or Russia before 1 June 2015” because of taking at face value the many media reports, around the world, and some from reputable sources, about his supposedly confirmed meeting with Putin in Moscow for the May Victory Day parade. I decided somewhat ahead of the crowd average that these were erroneous.  (Brier 0.211) Unreliability of these stories was detectable by the comparison classes of (1) how many times have major media outlets around the world published stories of North Korean executions and were subsequently embarrassed by the alleged victims turning up alive and with great careers in their homeland, and (2) how many heads of state had Kim Jong Un ever met (answer: 0). Latest example of clearly false recent news stories was the alleged visit of U.N. Geberal Secretary Ban Ki Moon coming up next Tuesday. This media balloon was popped yesterday when UN spokesman Stéphane Dujarric denied these stories. He pointed out that Ban has a full schedule elsewhere, spending most of next week in New York and next in Malta for the Commonwealth Summit starting on Nov. 27, followed by a climate conference in Paris starting Nov. 30.  Dateline 11-19-15 On Wednesday afternoon, Reuters quoted UN spokesman Stéphane Dujarric as denying the Xinhua report. He said Ban will spend most of next week in New York and then head to Malta for the Commonwealth Summit starting on Nov. 27, before a climate conference in Paris starting Nov. 30.  Diplomatic sources said the conflicting reports suggest Ban has reached some sort of tentative agreement to visit North Korea soon, but not when.  A UN source said, "It's not just the itinerary. It still has to be decided what form the visit will take, what the agenda will be, and who will accompany him. Without that it could just end up as a propaganda exercise for the North Korean regime." http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2015/11/19/2015111901714.html

This is a a good starting point for reviewing  North Korean nuclear testing issue NightWatch
For the Night of 29 October 2015

North Korea:  A South Korean government official disclosed this week that North Korea halted operations of its graphite-moderated 5 MW(e) reactor at Yongbyon in mid-October.

The South Korean government has increased its monitoring of Yongbyon because a halt in operations can mean that North Korea will soon extract the fuel rods from the core for reprocessing to produce plutonium.



Comment:  Commercial satellite imagery detected activation of the graphite-moderated reactor at Yongbyon in April. A six-month burn period for the core is about normal for North Korea.   Its technicians have pulled the core for reprocessing after short burn periods in the past. On the other hand, North Korea also has halted operations at Yongbyon after a short burn period because of the threat of a systems failure.

Pulling the core is not necessarily a preparation for a nuclear test, as some South Korean news services speculated. In the1990s pulling the core always meant preparations for producing more plutonium, the only nuclear weapons path the North Koreans had at that time. Based on their extensive experience with plutonium, they probably intend to make more plutonium-based weapons.

Still, a new warhead design would need testing. A South Korean news service quoted a government official who said that the North Koreans are digging another tunnel at the site used for North Korea’s three past tests. Personnel and vehicles are active at the site, indicating a test is not imminent.

Until North Korea activated the graphite-moderated reactor last April, it appeared that the North had switched to highly enriched uranium for use in its nuclear weapons. It is now clear that both paths for producing weapons-grade fissile material are available. That suggests the North is not bluffing when its propaganda talks about increasing its nuclear threat.

Winter is coming and it is almost always stressful on the North Korean economy and food distribution system.
